field.output: You have made changes to the fields in your dbdict. Below is the ALTER TABLE statement necessary to apply the corresponding changes to the SQL tables for this dbdict.
field.property: Wlabel;Caption=You have made changes to the fields in your dbdict. Below is the ALTER TABLE statement necessary to apply the corresponding changes to the SQL tables for this dbdict. Name=Wlabel0 ArrayLength=2 ForeColor=0 Height=4 Name=Wlabel0 Width=150 X=2 Y=2

field.output: You can have Service Manager apply these changes for you. This is the recommended way, as it will keep the dbdict and the SQL tables synchronized. If you need to, you can edit the statement first. Be careful, Service Manager passes the statement exactly as it is to your SQL DB. If it is incorrect, the results will be undesirable.
field.property: Wlabel;Caption=You can have Service Manager apply these changes for you. This is the recommended way, as it will keep the dbdict and the SQL tables synchronized. If you need to, you can edit the statement first. Be careful, Service Manager passes the statement exactly as it is to your SQL DB. If it is incorrect, the results will be undesirable. Caption=You can have Service Manager apply these changes for you. This is the recommended way, as it will keep the dbdict and the SQL tables synchronized. If you need to, you can edit the statement first. Be careful, Service Manager passes the statement exactly as it is to your SQL DB. If it is incorrect, the results will be undesirable. Name=Wlabel1 ArrayLength=3 ForeColor=0 Height=6 Name=Wlabel1 Width=150 X=2 Y=7

field.output: Or you can apply these changes outside of Service Manager. Until you do so, however, the dbdict and its mapping will be out of sync with the SQL tables. This could lead to application errors if not resolved.
field.property: Wlabel;Caption=Or you can apply these changes outside of Service Manager. Until you do so, however, the dbdict and its mapping will be out of sync with the SQL tables.
